bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Wyndham B. Blanton, May 23, 1941

div1.p: Hench requests information about the Walter Reed Memorial Day. He describes his research on the conquest of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Wyndham B. Blanton, May 23, 1941
div1.opener:
May 23, 1941
Dr. Wyndham Blanton
828 West Franklin Street
Richmond, Virginia
My dear Doctor Blanton:
div1.p:
Could you tell me anything about the Walter Reed Memorial Day? As a
hobby, I have spent the last three years studying the story of Walter Reed and
the conquest of yellow fever. I have uncovered some data regarding Walter Reed,
Lazear and others which has never been published. I have visited most of the
living survivors of the experiments and have made two trips to Cuba where I ran
into some most interesting experiences. The Cubans had lost track of Camp Lazear
and had wrongly located it, having bought property for a memorial on the wrong
site. By a lucky chain of events, I was able to discover the right place and
actually found the remains of one of the buildings used by Walter Reed--the famous
little Building No. 1. I have bought this building and I am hoping that we can buy
the remainder of Camp Lazear so that those who are interested in Walter Reed and
his colleagues can properly memorialize this spot, lost for forty years.

I thought that I would like to call the attention of some of the directors
of the Walter Reed Memorial Day to these findings, in the hope that they might be
willing to collaborate with me and with several others who have already agreed
to start a little campaign in behalf of this memorial. Those that I have so far
interested are General Kean of Washington, ex-Surgeon General Ireland, Dr. Howard
Kelly, General Truby and others. I happened to be discussing this with Dr. Jordan
of Richmond at the recent Atlantic City meeting, and he told me you would know
with whom I should get in touch. I appreciate this courtesy greatly.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
